long_desc.thetext:
base.json's "common" job has become a "hook" job for custom configs, meaning custom configs shadoe this job when they want to inject settings into all compile jobs.
- For one, this is not a published API, and people are not directed to this job to achieve the desired results. There should be a more dedicated include job for general compile settings (that are not already factored out into even more dedicated and truely published jobs, like 'cache' or 'libraries'). Something like "build-common" or "compile-common" or "script-settings".
- If sensible, other more specialized jobs could be added, if a catch-all "build-common" appears to coars-grained.
- This hook job should then be documented accordingly.
- base.json needs an internal job to share common settings, but with a different name, e.g. "base-common".
- Although this was never advised, maybe some thought should be spent on migration of the use of "common" job in custom configs.
